description.narrative: Construction of Makambako-Songea transmission line and distribution lines to provide sustained access to reliable and affordable electricity within six districts in the Iringa and Ruvuma regions of Southern Tanzania (Ref 71002060 credit part)

Konstruktion av Makambako-Songea transmission och distributions-linjer för tillgång till hållbar, tillförlig elektricitet till överkomligt pris inom sex distrikt i regionerna Iringa och Ruvuma i södra Tanzania.

The government of Tanzania has signed an agreement with the government of Sweden whereby the later has committed to providing support to the Makamako-Songea 220kV Transmission Line and Rural Electrification Project for a period of five years from 2008 to 2013; however, the financial agreement has been extended several times to end i June 2019. The last extension was proposed in late 2018 to cover the finalization of the project. However, the signing of the amendment is still stuck in the Ministry of Finance. This was initially planned as a five-year project and a total budget for implementing the project was SEK 500 Million. Out of this amount SEK 210 Million (concessional loan) is for the transmission part covering the overhead lines and substations, and SEK 290 Million (grant) is for the distribution part covering medium and low voltage lines, transformer stations and household connections. However, several amendments with time and cost increase has been made, which led to increase in the grant component up to SEK 358 411 000. The total contribution from Sweden now is SEK 568 411 000. The main objectives of the Makambako-Songea 220kV Transmission and Distribution project is to provide and improve supply of electricity to economic centers and households in rural villages, peri-urban areas and towns in Njombe and Ruvuma regions in Tanzania. The project will improve the living standard of the residents within the project area in many ways such as;- Improvement of social services such as good performance in schools, especially at secondary schools and improvement of health services in hospitals and clinics- Replacement of existing in total 10 MW diesel power stations in Songea (7MW), Mbinga (2MW), Namtumbo (650 kW) and Ludewa (350 kW) which leads to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and costs of purchasing transporting diesel from Dar es Salaam to Songea, Namtumbo, Mbinga and Ludewa. - Reduction of use of kerosene, firewood and charcoal, which will have positive impact on the environment - Also indirectly, establishment of small commercial and industrial business which may attract potential investors to further invest in these areas During the reporting period July 2018 - June 2019 Tanesco submitted the Annual Progress Report on the implementation of the project to the Embassy of Sweden, which will form the basis for this perfomance monitoring for the preparation of Conclusion on Perfomance. 1.Transmission Sub Project; The Transmission Sub Project consists of construction of 245 km of 220 kV overheadtransmission line from Makambako to Songea, extension of Makambako 220/132/33 kV substation and new construction of Madaba and Songea 220/33 kV Substations. Also, includes installation of a Fiber Optical Ground Wire (OPGW) for communication purposes. 2 Distribution Sub Project; The Distribution Sub Project consists of Consultancy Services and construction of 932 km of 33 kV distribution lines with installation of 282 of 33kV/400V transformers, Low Voltage distribution networks and connections to about 22,700 customers in 118 Villages in Districts of Njombe, Ludewa, Songea, Namtumbo and Mbinga in Njombe and Ruvuma regions. Whereby, connection of customers is in two phases, the first phase targets to connect 10,083 customers under main contract and the second phase targets to connect 12,617 customers under additional scope of the contract. During the reporting period the total connection is 15,650, the work is still in progress. Sources of Fund 1. Grant portion - Under the specific agreement, Sida contributes SEK 352.4 Million as grant to the project, including the additional funds that has been allocated through amendements, which allocated for the rural distribution component. 2. Credit Portion - Under the credit agreement, Sida issued a soft loan of SEK 210 Million via the Swedish Export Credit Agency (AB SEK) for Transmission subproject. The soft loan consist grant portion of SEK 168 plus the soft loan of SEK 42 Million. 3. Funds from the Governemnt of Tanzania- The Government of Tanzania provides additional fund of USD 13 Million to support Transmission and Substation part of the project and a further TZS 7 Billion for Compensation to people affected by the project. TANESCO also through Ministry of Energy (MoE) contributes USD 9 Million to support Transmission line upgrade. The approx total amount from the government is equivalent to SEK 230.6 Million. In this regard the contribution from the Government of Sweden is SEK 562.4 Millinon (71%) and from the Government of Tanzania is SEK 230.6 Million (29%).

sector.narrative: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

description.narrative: Distribution component:The project progress has been very slow and is 12 months behind schedule. The project delays are mainly caused by;(i) Isolux Poor financial situation and cash flow situation(ii) The lack of material for installation works due to late establishment of Letter of Credit(iii) Delay in opening of revised Letter of Credit.(iv) Delay payments under Change order no2(v) Delay of processing VAT exemption(vi) Introduction of Cess Tax on wooden poles from SAO HILL(vii) Less number of customers submitted to the contractor The solutions for all causes of project delay have already been issued/solved. With the time extension several times, the Contractor accomplished to construct all MV and LV networks, even though all customers in the contract has not been connected. During the reporting period 15 650 customers have been connected. According to the annual progress report shows that the actual Supply of Material is 100%, which will faiclitate reaching the connection target of 22,700. Transmission comonent: The contractor completed site mobilization in October 2016. Furthermore, plan and profile of the line from Makambako – Songea 250 km (711 Tower Locations) approved. Kalpataru has declared for Mechanical completion on the 30th of June 2018. Line route between Makambako and Madaba was final inspected and energized on the 8th of September 2018. Line route between Songea and Madaba was final inspected and energized on the 13th of September 2018. Completion Certificate was issued on the 15th February 2019 and warranty time period ends on the 15th of February 2020. The work is 100% completed. Substation component: Overall works for all three Substations are completed up to 100% and energized within contractual time.? - Makambako Substation was energized on the 2nd of September 2018.? - Madaba Substation was energized on the 10th of September 2018.? - Songea Substation was energized on the 15th of September 2018.Warranty Inspection? - Songea inspection was completed on the 16th of September 2019.? - Madaba inspection was completed on the 18th of September 2019.? - Makambako inspection was completed on the 20th of September 2019. The installation of 220/33 kV Substations with Joint Venture of M/S Shandong Taikai Power Engineering Co. Ltd. and M/S Norinco International Cooperation Ltd., as at June 2019 was 100% complete. However, this component was not supported by Sweden, but was necessary component for the completion of the project Overall performance of the project for the Substations and Transmission Line is 100% completed, and 70% completion for the distribution component, the work is still in progress for distribution component. The project was offcially innaugrated by H.E. President John Joseph Pombe Magufuli in April 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
